bibl.title: Letter from James D. Heard to Philip Showalter Hench, February 23, 1942

div1.p: Heard discusses Hench's research on the yellow fever experiments.

div1.head: Letter from James D. Heard to Philip Showalter Hench, February 23, 1942
div1.opener:
JAMES D. HEARD, M. D.
121 UNIVERSITY PLACE
PITTSBURGH, PA.
February 23, 1942.
Dr. Phillip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota.
Dear Hench:
div1.p:
Almost anyone but you would have been satisfied with the fine
job which you have already done on the conquest of yellow fever.
But you are a hound on the scent, and now I am looking forward with
impatience to the additional light which you will throw on this
important subject. Please keep me on your mailing list.

It is curious that my unimportant note to Mrs. Schweitzer
should have survived. I am glad that there is nothing incriminating
in it. In any case, it was good of you to send it to me.

Confound it! I hope you are still enjoying the
frontispiece in your edition of Withering. You are a lucky guy
and a good egg.
div1.closer: Affectionately yours, J D H JDH:H
